dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Delerue's theme from "Antoine and Colette" plays over an opening credit sequence consisting of a series of images Paris. Each shot is composition of the streets, landmarks and the minute details of this beautiful August afternoon The last shot begins wide on the Shakespeare Bookstore an closes in on a sign in the window announcing an event: "Jesse Wallace, young author of the acclaimed best-seller THIS TIME, Saturday, August 23." A brooding picture of Je is prominent. Over the image, we hear a French Journalist asking a question.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: Do you consider the book to be autobiographical?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside this funky bookstore, JESSE, early 30's, is sittin casually with a few journalists and patrons.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: isn't everything autobiographical, I mean we ail see the world from our own tiny keyhole. I always think of Thomas Wolfe - have you ever seen that little one page 'note to reader’ in the front of Look Homeward, Angel. Do you know what I'm talking about? Vague affirmatives. .

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Anyway, He says how we are the sum of all the moments of our lives, that anybody who writes will use the clay of their lives, that you can't avoid that. I remember he says he can't imagine anything more autobiographical then Gulliver's Travels.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over the next section of dialog, we see an approximately second series of shots from BEFORE SUNRISE that silently tell the story: boy meets girl on a train, boy and girl g to know one another, boy and girl kiss, get more intimate part at dawn.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: When I look at my life, I have to admit I've never been around a bunch +e ee  Betore Sunrise Sequei Pank Pages 24/8/03 “he

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: of guns or violence, a helicopter crash, political intrigue. But my life, from my point of view, has been full of drama. And one of the most exciting things that's ever happened to me is actually connecting with another person and I thought if I could write a book that could capture that, make that connection valuable, that possibility...anyway that was the attempt. I don't know if that answers your question... He kh OF

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: "ll be more specific. Was there ever a young French woman on a train you met and spent an evening with?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: See to me, that's not important.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: So, that's a yes?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay, since this is the last stop of my book tour and I am in France, Yes. We're now near the end of the montage where Celine and Je say their good-byes at the train station and are soon traveling alone.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: The book ends on an ambiguous note - we don't know. Do you think they get back together in six months like they promised each other?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I think how you answer that is a good test as to whether you ‘are a romantic or a cynic. * He looks at the journalists and points at each of them as speaks.  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03 3.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: You think they get back together, you don't, you hope they do but aren't sure.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: But do YOU think they do? Did you in real life?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Well, in the words of my grandfather, to answer that would take the piss outta the whole thing. Still offscreen, the Bookstore Manager chimes in.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: We have time for one last question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're now back inside.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: What is your next book?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I've always wanted to write a book where the whole thing happens within the space of one pop song.

dialogues.speaker: FRENCH JOURNALIST
dialogues.text: What song?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: T don't know, haven't written it yet - "the Long and Winding Road" maybe... The story's about this guy living in Miami at his in-laws beach house, and he's totally depressed. His great dream was to be an adventurer, a lover, riding motorcycles through South America. But instead, he sitting at this marble table eating lobster, He's got a job, a beautiful . wife, all that he needs, but none of it matters - what he wants is to fight for meaning. Across the room, CELINE emerges from behind a row of book where she's been hiding and listening.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Happiness is in the doing, right? not getting what you want.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8403 4.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: And just that second his five year- old daughter ‘jumps up on the table. He knows she shouldn't be there ~ she could get hurt. But she is dancing to this pop song in a summer dress. Celine is looking at him.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: All of sudden he's 16 and his high- school sweetheart is dropping him off at home. They just lost their virginity and she loves him and the same song is playing on the car radio, and she climbs up dancing on the roof of the car. And now he's worried about her. She's beautiful with a facial expression just like his daughter. Maybe that's why he likes her. He knows he is not REMEMBERING this dance. He is there - he is there in both moments simultaneously. In fact he pulls away from a kiss with the girlfriend so as to not offend his daughter. Both moments are real, happening together. For @ moment all his life is foiding in and it's obvious to him that time is a lie... He looks up and sees Celine for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Its all happening all the time and inside every moment, is another, all happening simultaneously. He takes a beat, still looking at Celine, not sure what t do next.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Anyway, that's kinda the idea, anyway.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Our author needs to be going to the airport soon. I'd like to thank all ef you for coming over this afternoon, and especially like to thank Mr. Wallace for being with us. We hope to see you again with your next book. So everyone, please help yourselves to champagne and cookies.  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03 5. There is polite applause and people start to disperse. Je looks back over to Celine - she gives a little wave. He gets the manager's attention.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: (to Manager} How long 'till I have to leave here for the airport?

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: You should leave about 7:15 or so, 7:30 at the latest.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay... Jesse walks over to Celine.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Hello. A slightly awkward double cheek kiss.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: How are you?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Good, and you?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Great. You wanna get some coffee or something?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Didn't he just say you have a plane to catch?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I have a little time. Want to get out of here?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yes? Jesse goes back over to the manager.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'll be back in thirty, forty-five minutes or so. We're just going to go get a cup of coffee.  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER
dialogues.text: Okay, but get your driver Phillipe's card so you'll have his cell phone. Call him if you're running late. SA.  Before Sunrise Sequel Green Pages 21/8/03 6.

dialogues.speaker: MANAGER, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: We'll get your bags in the car so you won't be late to the airport.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Okay. Thanks for everything. As they start to exit the store, Jesse is detained briefl signing a book, getting the card from the driver, etc. Ce exits in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Outside the bookstore, Jesse puts his hands on Celine's shoulders and just looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I can't believe you're here!

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I live here in Paris. Are you sure you don't have to stay? Aren't you supposed to talk to those people.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: It's okay, they're sick of me - I spent the night here last night.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: You did?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: They have a loft upstairs. How are you? This is so weird.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I'm fine. It's good to see you.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Tt's good to see you too.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: So you want to go to a cafe?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Sure.  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/87/03 7.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: There's one a little further, that I like a lot. ®@ JESSE Alright. They start walking.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I thought I was going to totally lose it in there after I saw you. How'd you even know I was going to be here?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: It's my favorite bookstore in Paris. You can sit down for hours, I love it - even if there's fleas.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I think a cat slept on my head last night.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I saw your picture on the calendar about a month ago and that you were going to be here. It's funny I read an article on your book and it sounded @ vaguely familiar, but I didn't put it all together until I saw the photo.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Did you have a chance to read it?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yes. I was really surprised as you can imagine. {a beat) I had to read it twice, actually. Jesse just looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Comme ci comme ca?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No, I really like it - it's romantic. I usually don't like that but it's well written. Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Thanks. e Celine suddenly stops and looks at Jesse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Sunrise Sequel Green Pages 21/8/03

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: But. before we go anywhere I have to ask you, did you show up in Vienna that December?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Did you? TA.  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I couldn't, but did you? I have to know. It's important to me.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: (playful) Why, if you didn't?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Did you?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Oh thank God you didn't. JESSE. Yeah, thank God you didn't either. If one of us would have been there alone, it would have sucked. They continue walking.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I know, I was so concerned with that. I've always felt horrible about not being there but I couldn't, my grandma died a few days before and she was buried that day, December 16th.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: {almost relieved) She died? The one in Budapest?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: How did you remember that?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I remember everything.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Oh, of course, it was in your book. Anyway, I was just about to fly to Vienna to meet you when we got the news about her, then of course I went to the funeral with my parents.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I'm so sorry to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03 9.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: But you weren't there anyway. (suddenly suspicious) Wait, why weren't you there? If would have been there if I could have - I had made plans. You better have a good reason. They slow to a stop and just look at each other. She real he's. been lying.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Oh no! You were there, weren't you?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: {down} Yeah,

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Ahhhh! That's terrible! I'm so sorry. I'm laughing but Tf don't mean it. Did you hate me? You must have hated me. (a beat) Have you hated me all this time?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yes you have, but you can't hate me now.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No... I don't hate you. C'mon, no big deal. I flew over there, you blew the whole thing off, I gave up on love, and my life's been a big nose-dive since then, but hey, no big deal.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No!

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I'm kidding.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I can't believe it. You must have felt really angry with me. I'm so sorry ~ I wanted to be there more than anything in the world. But you can't be angry anymore, I mean my grand-ma~-~

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Sunrise Sequel Green Pages 21/8/03 10.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Honestly, I had a feeling something like that might have happened. I was bummed, but I was mostly just mad that we hadn't exchanged phone numbers or any information.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I know, that was so stupid - no way to get in touch, I didn't even know your last name.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I know! We had nothing to go on.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I was cursing... - If I could just reach him. .

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I know, remember the reason we did that...we were both afraid if we started calling and writing it would slowly fade away.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: It definitely wasn't a slow fade.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Sure wasn't.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yes, we wanted to pick it up where we left off, which would have been a good idea if...

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: (butting in) If it'd just worked! Oh well.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: So how long were you in Vienna?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Couple of days. .

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Did you meet another girl?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, her name was Gretchen, she was awesome. The book's actually a composite of the two of you...  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Really?!

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No... I even went back to the train station and put up a sign that had the number to my hotel, just in case you had been delayed a half day or something... total dork.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Did you get any calls?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Just a couple of hookers looking for a gig. (a beat) Hey, it was awful, what do you want me to say?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Oh, that's so sad. I'm so sorry. They start walking again.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Then I just walked around for a while then eventually flew back home. I owed my dad two grand, who had warned me about French chicks.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: What did he tell you about French women?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Nothing, lots of crap. He's never been with any French women. I don't think he's ever been east of the Mississippi.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Why didn't you put the six months later part in the book?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: But I did!

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I wrote a fictional version where you do show up.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: You did? What happens?  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Oh, we make love for like ten days straight... 1l~A.  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: That's interesting.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: And then they find out more about each other and realize they don't really get along.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I like that.., It's more real.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: My editor didn't feel that way.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yes, everybody wants to believe in ilove. ft sells.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yep.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: But things are going well for you, right? {pause} Your book's a bestseller in the U.S.?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: It's a tiny bestseller, but officially, yes. But hey, most people haven't read Moby Dick, so why the hell should they read my book?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I never read Moby Dick, but I liked your book, even though I thought you idealized our night a bit.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Hey, it's fiction.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: i know, but I thought there wete times when you made me, I mean her, no, me, like sometimes she's was a bit... psychotic.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: But you are a little like that.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: i know... Whatil!

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Just kidding. No really, where’d I do that?
Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Maybe it’s just me...It was so strange to be reading something knowing the character in the story is based on you. It's both flattering and disturbing at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Why was it disturbing?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I don't know, just -being part of someone's memory, suddenly seeing myself through your eyes. How long did it take you to write it?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: On and off, 3 or 4 years.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: It's a long time to be writing about one night.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Tell mea about it. I feel like I basically lived with you there for a while.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I'd always assumed you've forgotten me.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: T had a pretty clear picture of you in my mind. I gotta tell you something - I've wanted to talk to you for so long...

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: It's surreal, now I feel everything I say should be...

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah, and now we have what? twenty minutes and thirty seconds?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: More than that, much more than that. I want to know about you. What are you up to? 13.  Before Sunrise Sequel Green Pages 21/8/03 13A.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Wheew. Where to start. I'm working for Green Cross, it’s an environmental organization.  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03 14.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Wow. What are they all about?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: We basically work on many different environment issues, from clean water to disarmament of chemical weapons you know, international laws that deal with the environment.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What do you do for them?

dialogues.speaker: CELINS
dialogues.text: Different things. Last year I was in India for quite a while working on a water treatment plant.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE,
dialogues.text: The cotton industry there is a major source of pollution.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I gotta say I admire the fact that it sounds like you are actually DOING something. Most people, myself included, just bitch about everything: how America's consuming all the world's resources, we're creating sweat shops in China, SUVs suck global warming...

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I'm relived to hear you're not one of those Freedom Fry kind of Americans.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Nah. But I gotta say, I think that's S80 cool what you're doing. How'd you get into that?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: When I.came out of political science I thought I'd be working for the government, and I did for a short while and then I got tired of having conversations with friends about how the world was falling to pieces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Sunrise Sequel Green Pages 21/8/03 14K.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I realized that the only thing I wanted to do was to look at things that really can be fixed and try to e@ fix them.  Before Sunrise Sequel He laughs.
hey bo c Pink Pages 24/8/03 15.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I gotta say, that's awesome. I always figured you'd be doing something cool like that.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Thanks. I'm lucky to have a job I really like.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You know, I actually alternate in thinking that everything is irrevocably screwed up, and actually feeling things in a general might be getting better.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Better! How could “you possibly think that?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I know it sounds weird, but I think there are things to be optimistic about.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: (interrupting) Okay, I know your book is selling, but what are you talking about - the world's a mess right now.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: rom a western point of view things are getting a bit better - we're moving all our industry to developing nations to get cheap labor free from any environmental laws. The weapons industry is out of control, five million die every year due to preventable water diseases. So how is the world getting better? I'm not getting angry, but really I want to know?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I know there are a lot of serious problems - I don't have one publisher in the entire Asian market. laugh, approaching the cafe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Sunrise Sequel Green Pages 21/8/03 15A.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But I think there's more awareness out there.  é Before Sunrise Sequel Green Pages 21/8/03 16.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It might be getting better because people like you are informed and educated and speaking out and as the world's consciousness and education vises - things like women's issues, racial rights, sexual rights, children's rights...

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I mean the very notion of conservation and environmental issues - all that weren't even in the vocabulary until fairly recently - those are becoming the norm and will eventually be what's expected all over the world.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: IT agree with what you are saying but it's dangerous. An imperialist country can use that kind of thinking to justify their economic greed. Human rights is the only issue I...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk in and eventually seat themselves.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Any particular imperialist country you got in mind there, Frency?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No, not really. Is it okay if we sit here?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Perfect. But what I'm really saying is the world might be evolving like a person evolves. ME for example... Am I improving? Am I getting worse? When I was younger I was healthier but I was racked with insecurity- Now I'm older my problems are deeper, but I'm more equipped to handle them.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: What are your problems? Long Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Right now, I don"t feel like I have any - just damn happy to be here.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Me too. How long have you been in Paris?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Got in last night. I've done ten cities in twelve days - I'm so glad it's over. I'm so sick of being a huckster The waitress comes over to the table.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: Bonjour. Vous dinner?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Just a coffee.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Non, un cafe, et une orange pressee avec des glacons,.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I love the coffee over here so much more than in the U.S.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I couldn't even drink coffee when I was living over there.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You lived in the U.S.? When?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: From '96 through '99. I was studying at NYU.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Don't tell me that!

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Ch wow - that’s weird. I've been in New York since '98. That's wild - we were both there at the same time. 17.  Before Sunrise Sequel Green Pages 21/8/03 18.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: That is weird. You know, it actually crossed my mind, if I might run into you there, but the odds are so slim, e you know? I had no idea even what town you were living in. Weren't you somewhere in Texas?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I was for a long time but, I had to get out there. I figured it was time for me to be in New York. What made you come back here?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: IT had finished my master's, for one, but I was starting to get paranoid. The stuff in the medias all the time - murders, gang violence, serial killers.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: i know.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I was living in terror. The final straw was one night I heard some noise on my fire escape, I called 911 and the cops came...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like three hours later.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE,
dialogues.text: After I'd been raped and killed about ten times. It was a man and a woman officer. I was describing to them what I had heard when the woman had to run downstairs to move the police car. I was alone with the male cop, and right away he asked me if I had agun. I said no and he told me I'd better think about getting one - this was America, not France. I told him I didn't know how to shoot . a gun and that I wasn't interested in firearms. That is when he pulled out his gun and said to me... {cop voice) "One day you're going to have something like this in your face, and if you want to live a long life, you're going to have to choose between  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: you or them." They left and the next morning, I actually called for an application to get a gun. Me, a @ gun! But then I started thinking that something was wrong, the way that cop had pulled his gun.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: So I canceled my demand for a gun and instead I called the police station and tried to complain about this cop's behavior.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE -
dialogues.text: What happened with that?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: It was so much paper work and with my shitty student visa, so I gave up and forgot about the whole thing. Well, actually no, I never forgot.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Obviously. @ Coffee arrives.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: But still, I wouldn't mind being back there - there's a lot of things I miss about the U.S.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Like what?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: The overall good mood people have even if it can be bullshit. Like “hey, how you doing? Great! How YOU doin? Great! Have a great day." Parisians are so grumpy. Have you noticed?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Really? Everyone around here seems pretty happy to me.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: They're not happy. Maybe I just mean the French men, they drive me @ nuts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What about them? 24/8/03 19A.  Before Sunrise Sequel Green Pages 21/8/03

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: You know, French guys like wine, and food, they're fun, maybe it's just me, bad luck, but there not that..-

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What? 19B.  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03 20.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: What's the word... horny.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: In that regard, I'm proud to be an ‘merican.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: And you should be ~ in that regard only. Have you ever spent any time in Eastern Europe?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I remember as a teenager I went to Warsaw when it was still a strict communist regime, which I don't approve of at all.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Sure you don't.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I don't at all, really. But something about being there after a while was very interesting, I found. After a couple of weeks something changed in me. The city was quite gloomy and gray but after a while my brain seemed Clearer. I was writing a lot more in my journal, ideas I had never thought of before.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Communist ideas?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Shut up! I'm not a communist.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I know. Go ahead, sorry.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: It took me a while to figure out why, why I felt so different. And then, one day as I was walking throvgh the Jewish cemetery, I don't know why but it occurred to me there, i realized I had just spent the past couple of weeks away from most of my habits. The TV was in a language I didn't understand and there was nothing to buy, no advertisements anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03 20A.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So all I had been doing for three weeks was walk around, write, think. My brain felt like it was at rest, free from the consuming frenzy and 1 have to say it was almost like a natural high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Sunrise Sequel Green Pages 21/8/03 20B.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I was so peaceful inside, no strange urges to be somewhere else, to shop.  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03 21.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Maybe it could have seemed like boredom at first but it quickly it became very soulful.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Can you believe it was nine years ago we were walking around Vienna?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No, that's impossible.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Feels like two months ago... but dune of "94.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: De I look any different?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Mommm. Your hair was down back then, can you... She undoes her hair. Jesse keeps looking at her.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Little skinnier I think.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Was I fat before?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No, no.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: You thought I was a fatty. You wrote a book about a fat girl. They both laugh.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No seriously - you look beautiful. Do I look any different?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No... you have this little line here. She points to the wrinkle between his eyebrows.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I know, I know.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Like a scar.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: A scar? Like a gunshot wound?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No, I like it. I had a terrible nightmare the other day. I was having an awful dream that I was 32, then i woke up and I was 23, relieved, and then I woke up for real and I was 32.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Aw shit, it happens.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Time gets faster and faster. Apparently it's because we don't renew our synapses after 20, so it's all pretty much downhill from then on.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: On the other hand, I like getting older. Life feels more immediate - You can appreciate it more.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Oh I know. I actually like it too.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I was once a drummer in a band.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: You were?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: And we were pretty good too. But the lead singer was so obsessed with us getting signed. We spent all our time thinking about getting bigger gigs- all about the future. And now the band doesn't even exist anymore. 22.  Before Sunrise Sequel Green Pages 21/8/03 22A.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But looking back at those shows we did, even rehersing, it was so much fun.  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I think now I'd be able to enjoy every minute of it.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Well, you've got your book published and you're travelling ali over the They laugh. world with it... are you enjoying it?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Not really.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: You know in my field, I see some people that come into it like with big idealist visions, of becoming the new leaders that will create a better world, they enjoy the goal but not the process.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Right .

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: But the reality of it is that the true work of improving things is in the little achievements of the day, and that's what you need to enjoy to stay in that field. For example I worked for an organization that helped villages in Mexico and their concerns was how to get the pencils sent to the kids in those little country schools, it was not about discussing big revolutionary ideas about a better world - it was about pencils. I see the people that do the real work, and what in a way is really sad is that the people that are often the most giving, hard working and capable of making this world better don’t really have the ambition and ego to be a leader, they don't see any interest in the rewards, they don’t care if their name ever appear in the press, they actually enjoy the process of helping others, they are truly in the moment.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, that's such a struggle.
toh OF

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03 23A.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: It seems like we're designed to be slightly dis-contented with everything. Always trying to better @ our situation. You satisfy one desire and it just agitates another. But then I think, well, desire is the fuel of life. Do you think it's true that we'd never be unhappy if we never wanted anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Sunrise Sequel Green Pages 21/8/03 24.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I don't know actually. Not wanting anything... Isn't it a symptom of depression? it's very human to desire.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: That's what all those Buddhist cats say, right, liberate yourself from desire and you will find you already have everything you need.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: But I feel human when I want something more than just basic survival needs. Wanting, whether it's intimacy with another person or a new pair of shoes is kind of beautiful. I like that we have ever-renewing desires.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah... I guess it's just entitlement that brings all the pain. Whenever you feel you deserve that pair of shoes, that your desires SHOULD be met. It's all right to have wants and needs as long as you don't get angry when they're not realized. Life is hard, it's supposed to be, if we didn't suffer we would never learn a thing.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: So what, are you like a Buddhist or something?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: i don't know, it's probably like when I go to a museum I don't get - the headphones with the guided tour.  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I know. I decided a long time ago that I wanted be open to everything, but not buy into any one belief system.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I like that. I went to this Trappist monastery @ couple years ago.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Trappist?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Catholic, Cistertian.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Why did you go there?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I don't know, I'd been doing a bunch of reading, thought it'd be cool. Have you ever spent time with any monks or nuns?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Not my style.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I was shocked - I expected them to be ail glowering and stern but they weren't - they were quick to laugh and really easy to be around, very attuned to everything. They're not trying to hustle anybody, they're not trying to accomplish anything, they are trying to live and die in peace and be close with God or whatever part of them they feel is eternal - it's so refreshing to be around. You realize that the bulk of people that you meet are trying to get somewhere better, make a little more jack, get a little more respect, have more people admire them... it's exhausting.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No kidding.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: And it's exhausting to be one of those people yourself. 25.  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03 26.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm at a monastery, greedy to be a little more spiritual, "I want to be a better person." You can't escape.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I had a boyfriend many years ago that wanted to be a Buddist and he went to Asia to visit several monasteries. He was very good looking and everytime he went to one of those monasteries a monk offered to suck his cock. They laugh. He laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Well, it all comes down to that, doesn't it? That's why I think I really admire what you're doing.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: You mean sucking cock?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No. I'm just saying it sounds like you're not detached from the world. You're putting your life and passion into tangible action,

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I'm just doing my best.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You know something?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I'm going to be sitting down on a plane and in airports for the next eight hours or something. Would you - mind walking around with me a little bit?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Are you inviting me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03 27.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yes, let's go. They stand up. He glances at the bill and takes out a fiv Euro note.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Is this enough? Even for a tip?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yep. They start walking out.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Anywhere to walk to around here?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: t's sales day today.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: It's when everything is on sale in Paris. Twice a year.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Then let's go shopping.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No, no, no, I don't want to inflict that on you - it's madness. Let's go up to the garden path - it's a nice way back.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: That sounds better than shopping, actually, not that I wasn't up for doing anything you wanted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are walking, approaching the garden path.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sometimes, I can get high on just looking and trying on things, I don't even need to buy.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: A therapist would tell you it's all good.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Are you ever in therapy? +o Ot  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03 278.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Does it seem like I’m in therapy?  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: t don't know - has it helped your sex problems?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: (wide eyed) Sex problems?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No, I'm kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They continue their walk/talk.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No, no, tell me the truth. Did we have problems that night?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I was kidding. We didn't even have sex anyway.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What? That's a joke, right?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No, we didn't. That was the whole thing.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Of course we did.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: But we didn't. You didn't have a condom and I never have sex without one, especially if it was a one night thing. I'm extremely paranoid about my health.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I'm finding this very scary that you don't remember what happened.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: You know what, I didn't write an entire book, but I kept a journal and I wrote the whole night in it. That's what I meant by you idealizing the night.  Before Sunrise Sequel Green Pages 21/8/03 29.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: (a bit louder) I even remember the brand of condom I used.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: That's disgusting. Walking by are an older couple with three kids. They look back, a bit shocked.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No it isn't.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Alright, when I get home, T'il check my journal from '94, but I know I'm right. . {a beat} Wait a minute. Was it in the cemetery?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Noooc. We visited the cemetery during the day. It was in a4 park, very late at night.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Wait a minute.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Was it that forgettable? You don't remember, in the park?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Wait a minute, I think you might be right.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You're messing with me.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Sorry, no you're right. It's strange sometimes it's like I put things in drawers inside my head and forget about it.  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03 30.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I guess it is less painful to put certain things away than to live with it.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: So that night was a sad memory for you?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I didn’t mean that night in particular. I meant that certain things are better off forgotten.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: God, I remember that night better than entire years.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Me too, I mean I thought I did. Maybe I put it away because of the fact that my Grandmother's funeral was the day we we're supposed to meet again.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: It was a bad day for me, but it must've been even worse for you.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yeah it was unreal, I looked at her dead body in the coffin, I looked at her hands that used to hold me, so warm, so sweet, but nothing in that coffin resembled what I remembered of her. All the warmth was gone. I was crying looking at her, so confused about if I was crying because I was never going to see her again or never going to see you again. Sorry to go on like this, but I've been a little down this week.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: why?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Forget it, nothing bad, reading your book maybe. Thinking of how hopeful I was that summer and fall and since then it's kind of... I don't know, memory is a wonderful thing it you don't have to deal the past.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03 31. He laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Can I make a bumper sticker out of @ that? MEMORY IS A WONDERFUL THING IF YOU DON'T HAVE TO DEAL WITH PAST. If you wrote a book about our night, that could be the title.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yes, I guess it would have been a different book.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: It wouldn't have a sex scene.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: But you know what —- now that we've met again we can change our memory of Dec. 16th - it no longer has that sad ending of us never seeing each other again.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, a memory’s never finished if you really think about it.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yes I know, I have memories from my @ childhood that I realized more recently never really happened. My mom was so paranoid when I was eight or nine she was always warning me when I walked home at night from my piano lesson about dirty old men giving me candies and showing me their pee-pees. Jesse laughs.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: As I got older I had this image in my head that this had really happened. To the point that I associated sex with that walk home. And now - sometimes when I am having sex I see myself walking down that street.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Is that street nearby? They laugh.  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03 32.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Did you ever keep a journal as a kid?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I started when I was about * thirteen. *

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Me too. It's funny I read mine from "83 the other day. What really surprised me is that I was dealing with life the same way I am now. I was much more naive and hopeful, but the core, and the way I was feeling things is exactly the same as it is now. I haven't changed much at all.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I don't think anyone does. No one wants to admit it, but it's like we have these innate set points, and nothing much is going to change our general disposition.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Do you believe that?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: The older I get, I think maybe so. I read about this study where they * followed people that had won the * lottery and people who'd become paraplegics. We're led to believe one would make us euphoric and the other suicidal. The study showed * that within about six months, once they'd more or less gotten used to their new situation, they were fundamentally the same as they were before.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: The same?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, if they were basically an optimistic, jovial person, they were an optimistic, jovial person in a wheeichair. If they were a petty, miserable person, they were now 4 petty miserable person with a new house, Cadillac and boat.  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03 32A.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: You mean I'll be forever depressed no matter what great things happen in my life?  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03 He laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Definitely. Are you depressed now?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No. I'm not depressed but I worry I'll get to the end of my life feeling I haven't done all I wanted to do.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What do you want to do?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I mean J want to paint, write more songs, learn Chinese, play my guitar each day. There are so many things that I want to do, and I end up doing not much.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Well let me ask you this: do you believe in ghosts, or spirits?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Do you believe in re-incarnation?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Not at all.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What about God?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No, no. Jesse laughs.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: But at the same time, I don't want to be one of those people that don't believe in any kind of magic.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: So you believe in Astrology.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Of course! I mean, your a Scorpio, I'm a Sag, we get along. No. There's that Einstein quote that if you don't believe in any kind of magic or mystery, you're as good as dead. 33.  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03 33A.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I've always felt there was some kind of mystical core to the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Sunrise Sequel Green Pages 21/8/03 33B.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: universe. But I don't believe that me, my personality, has any permanent place here. And the more I believe that, the more I can't go through life and think "This is no big deal.” This is it. What do you see? What do you feel? What do you think is funny? Every day is the last.  Before Sunrise Sequel Green Pages 21/8/03 34.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: And sometimes when I feel that way I call my mom and I tell her I love her, she’s always... {imitating mother} "Oh my God, what's wrong? You've got cancer? You're going to commit suicide?" t's almost not worth it. Jesse laughs.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: So what about us?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What about us?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: For example if we knew we were both going to die tonight...

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Like the apocalypse was coming?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No, that's too dramatic. Just the two of us would die, would we talk about your book, the environment or, like tell me what you would you say.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: If today was our last day?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: That's hard, no?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I would definitely stop talking about my book, probably drop the environment...

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Okay. JESSE . I wouldn't mind still talking about magic in the universe, I'd just like to do it in a hotel room in between sessions of us like, wildly fucking till we die.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Wow. Why not just go over to that bench right there? Why waste time going to a hotel?  Before Sunrise Sequel Green Pages 21/8/03 34A. He immediately grabs her and pulls over to a bench. He tw her into his lap as she is suddenly overcome with shyness

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Well, we're most likely not gonna die tonight.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Too bad.  Before Sunrise Sequel Yellow Pages 20/8/03 She repositions herself on the bench next to him. 34B.  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03 35.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Forget about the hotel or the park bench.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Well let's not forget about it.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: That was an extreme example but my point was to communicate with people is very hard to do.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: And I feel the same. I'm sorry I had to let it all out. I'm miserable in my love life, in my relationship. I always act like I'm detached but I'm dying inside. I'm dying because I'm so numb. I don't feel pain or excitement. I'm not bitter, I'm just... The car makes it’s way through the streets of Paris, Celi and Jesse continue talking in the back seat.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Oh God, you think you are the one dying inside -My life is 24/7 bad. The ONLY happiness I get is when I'm out with my son. I've been to couples' counseling, things I'd never thought I'd have to do. Bought self help books, lingerie, lit candles... e CELINE Did the candles help?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Hell no. I don't love her the way she needs to be loved. I don't even see a future for us but then I look across the table at my beautiful boy and I think I would suffer any torture to wake up in his house and be with him for all the minutes of his life ~ I don't want to miss out on that. But man, there is no joy or laughter in my home and I don't want him growing up in that.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No laughter. My parents are still together for thirty-five years - and even when they have a fight they end up laughing.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I don't want to be one of those people getting divorced at fifty-two falling  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03 53. A pause.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: down into tears admitting that they never loved their spouse and feel like they've lost their life into a vacuum Cleaner, I want a great LIFE. I want her to have a great life, she deserves that. But we're living in the pretense of marriage, responsibility, these ideas of how people are supposed to live. I have these dreams all the time...

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: What dreams?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I wasn't going to say this, but I have these dreams where I'm standing on a platform and you keep going by on a train, again and again and again and then I wake up with the fuckin' sweats. And then there's this other dream where you are pregnant beside me in bed naked and I want to touch you so bad but you tell me not to and then you look away and I touch you anyway, right on your ankle, and your skin is so soft and I wake up in sobs and my wife is sitting there looking at me and I am ten million miles from her and I know something is wrong and I can't keep living like this. There's got to be more to love than commitment. I have to tell you I put the whole idea of romantic love to bed when you weren't there that day I swore it off.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Why are you telling me all this?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I'm sorry - maybe I should't have. .

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Isn't it weird that people always think that they are the only one getting through tough times? I thought from the article you must've had the perfect life- wife, kid, published author- but it sounds like your personal life is more of a mess than mine.  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Greaaaat! The car stops in from of her address. the driver. 24/8/03 Celine leans up to 53A.  12 Before Sunrise Sequel Green Pages 21/8/03 54.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Rentrez dans l'impasse, vous pouvez pas restez la, mais arretez vous sous l'arche.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Are you relieved that I'm even more in deep shit than you are?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Yes. You've made me feel better.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Good, I'm glad.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: You know I really wish you the best. It's not because I'm incapable of having a family that I wish everyone to be doomed like me.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I'm sure you'd be a great mother.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Really, you think so?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: A few anti-depressants and you'll do great. She raises her hand and starts moving her fingers quickly

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Say stop.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Stop. She does, with the middle finger extended. Then again (?) They step out the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They get out at Celine’s apartment, near an arched entran to a long corridor.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Here. I want to test something. She moves over to Jesse and gives him a big, long hug-  Before Sunrise Sequel Green Pages 21/8/03 55.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I'm seeing if you are going to dissolve into molecules or if you stay together. Jesse is almost shaking.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: How am I doing?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Still here.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Good. I’m liking still being here. They slowly part. Jesse turns to the driver.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Je la racompagne a as porte, ca ne vous ennuie pas trop.

dialogues.speaker: JEAN
dialogues.text: Aucun probleme. Je suis paye a itheur

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They start walking down the corridor toward a courtyard.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: So it is all really true about your dream, or did you say all that just to hopefully get in my pants?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: dust to get in your pants - I use that all the time. God, you live here, this is incredible! How long have you been here?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Four years. She sees a cat lounging on the cobblestones ahead of them CELINE (CONT'D) . Oh, there's my cat, look at him he's so cute. What I love about this cat is that every morning I bring him down to the courtyard. And every single morning he looks at everything iike its the first time, every plant, every tree, every little corner. He smell's everything with his little cute nose. I love my cat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before Sunrise Sequel Yellow Pages 20/8/03 56. She picks him up and continues walking, they enter a gian beautiful courtyard.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: What's his name?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Che.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Commie !

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Che, in Argentina means "Hey"! Neighbors are organizing a picnic dinner. Kids run around playing some kind of game. An older man sits with others eating salad and Melon. -

dialogues.speaker: OLDER MAN
dialogues.text: (in french) Celine! Tu nous fais quoi ce soir?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Taboule, je ie descends dans une minute.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER MAN
dialogues.text: Salut.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Salut. A woman in her early 60's comes up to Celine coming out o building with a dish.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Salut! C'est gui celui la il est mignon. Il mange avec nous.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Non il prend l'tavion.

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Tant pis pour lui, il goutera pas mes pattes aux poids chiches.

dialogues.speaker: OLDER MAN
dialogues.text: Pourquoi y mange pas avec nous?

dialogues.speaker: WOMAN
dialogues.text: Il aime pas ton short.  13 Before Sunrise Sequel Yellow Pages 2078/03 57.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk towards her door. She looks up at the late afternoon sky. They are on her doorstep. Moment of truth.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: You know what, I want you to play me a song.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: But you'll miss your plane.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Cimon. We got a little more time. I'm going to be sitting around the airport for well over an hour. She thinks about it, wondering...

dialogues.speaker: JESSE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: Seriously, one song.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Ok, but quick. She gets out her keys and opens the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the lobby of the building they are confronted by @ big winding stairway with a little elevator in the middle.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Tt love these kind of stairways. What floor are you on?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Third. They start up the stairs, not saying anything, but acting like everything is normal. As they continue in silence, t charged undertone seems even more pronounced. Eventually they reach her front door. She pulls out her keys and ope the door. She closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He awkwardly looks around while she heads to the kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Would you like some tea?  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03 58.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Sure. As she prepares a couple of glasses, we see the details o her apartment through his eyes. Some paintings, a picture of her as a child, a photo of her with her grandmother. A cat meanders over the window sill. He eventually comes ac an article and a picture of himself pinned up on a bullet board, He notices her guitar sitting by the sofa. She walks out the kitchen and gives him a glass.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Is camomile okay?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Yeah, sure. ThankS. Merci.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Messy? My apartment is messy?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No - merci.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I see your French has improved.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Oh yeah, I'm practically fluent. So what song are you going to play me?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: No, I can't. I'm embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Wait a minute. I come all the way over here... You can't crap out on me now. Anything will be great.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Uhhh. Okay, but you're going to laugh at me.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I doubt it.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Which one do you want? I only have three in English: the one about my cat, my ex-boyfriend or the one about you?  Before Sunrise Sequel Pink Pages 24/8/03 59.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Ahhh... sounds like a trick question. Give me the ex-boyfriend.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: The ex-boyfriend, really? She sits on the couch, all hippie style, and strums a beautiful, funny song. All Jesse can do is sit across from her on the sofa and s When Celine eventually finishes, he applauds.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Wheeeew! Encore! That was awesome! Now the one about me. CELINE. No, no, no. Have your tea and then you have te get going. She gets up and goes into the kitchen. While she's in the Jesse pokes around through her cds. By the time she retur a Nina Simone song is playing and he is sitting on the co

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: Is it okay if IT put my feet up?

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: Sure. Did you ever see Nina Simone in concert?

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: No, I wish I had. I can’t believe she's gone.

dialogues.speaker: CELINE
dialogues.text: I know, it's so sad. I saw her play twice. She was great. This is one of my favorites of hers. The song begins: "Just in time you've found me just in time Before you came my time was running low  Before Sunrise Sequel Green Pages 21/8/03 60. I was lost the losing dice were tossed My bridges all were crossed nowhere to go Now you hear now I know just where I'm going No more doubt of fear I've found my way For love came just in time you've found me just in time And changed my lonely nights that lucky day”

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: She used to stop right in the middle of a song, and walk from behind the piano over to the edge of the stage. Then she'd talk to somebody in the audience. ~ {imitating Nina) "Oh yeah, baby," She'd walk off a Little, then walk really slow back over to the mike. She had a big ass, and this funny little walk. Celine sort of hunches over and sticks out her butt a lit and proceeds to waddle slowly across the room. As the son keeps going, and Celine keeps clowning around, Jesse just sits there with the most peaceful, happy grin we've ever seen on him. "Just in time Before you came my time was running low oh baby I was lost the losing dice were tossed My bridges all crossed nowhere to go Now you hear now I know just where I'm going No more doubt of fear I've found my way For love came just in time you've found me just in time And changed my lonely nights and changed my lonely nights And changed my lonely nights and changed my lonely nights And changed my lonely nights that lucky day.”

dialogues.speaker: CELINE, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: {imitating Nina Simone) Yo baby, You gonna miss that plane.  Before Sunrise Sequel Green Pages 21/8/03 60A.

dialogues.speaker: JESSE
dialogues.text: I know.  Before Sunrise Sequel Yellow Pages 20/8/03 They both smile. the end 61.
